questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a persistent skin rash. Initially, she had an itchy, ring-shaped rash that partially resolved with a topical ointment. However, within a week of discontinuing the treatment, the itching returned and the rash spread. She denies any new products or environmental exposures. Physical examination reveals poorly demarcated, erythematous plaques with slight scaling scattered over her face, as shown in the image below. There are no vesicles, pustules, or signs of systemic illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tinea incognito

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tinea incognito is a fungal infection that has been altered by the inappropriate use of topical corticosteroids. This condition often presents with atypical features compared to a classic dermatophyte infection. The history of initial improvement with a topical ointment (likely a corticosteroid) followed by a return and worsening of symptoms after discontinuation is characteristic of tinea incognito. The poorly demarcated erythematous plaques with slight scaling observed on physical examination support this diagnosis. The use of corticosteroids suppresses the inflammation and itching temporarily but allows the fungal infection to proliferate more aggressively once the treatment is stopped.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tinea corporis : This typically presents with well-demarcated, annular, scaly plaques with central clearing and an active border, which is not the case here.
  • • Option A. Tinea corporis
  • • Option B. Tinea cruris : Usually affects the groin area and is also characterized by well-demarcated borders and central clearing, which is not consistent with the facial distribution and poorly demarcated lesions observed here.
  • • Option B. Tinea cruris
  • • Option D. Tinea capitis : This affects the scalp and hair, presenting with scaly patches, hair loss, and sometimes black dots. The facial distribution and presentation described do not match tinea capitis.
  • • Option D. Tinea capitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea incognito should be suspected when a dermatophyte infection worsens after the use of topical steroids, leading to atypical presentation and distribution of the lesions.

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Entameoba histolytica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Entamoeba histolytica is the cause of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon, distinguishing it from other intestinal pathogens due to its invasive capabilities and the characteristic morphology of the ulcers it creates. Understanding these features helps in the differential diagnosis of dysentery and guides appropriate treatment and management strategies.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Nuchal Translucency (NT):
  • • Nuchal Translucency (NT):
  • • Definition: Nuchal translucency refers to the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck. Significance: An increased NT measurement is associated with an increased risk for fetal aneuploidy (such as Down syndrome) and various structural anomalies including cardiovascular defects, hydrops fetalis, and cystic hygroma.
  • • Definition: Nuchal translucency refers to the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • • Definition:
  • • Significance: An increased NT measurement is associated with an increased risk for fetal aneuploidy (such as Down syndrome) and various structural anomalies including cardiovascular defects, hydrops fetalis, and cystic hygroma.
  • • Significance:
  • • Timing:
  • • Timing:
  • • NT is measured between 11 weeks and 13 weeks 6 days (or 11-14 weeks ) of gestation. This time frame is critical as it ensures the accuracy of the measurement and its correlation with potential anomalies.
  • • NT is measured between 11 weeks and 13 weeks 6 days (or 11-14 weeks ) of gestation. This time frame is critical as it ensures the accuracy of the measurement and its correlation with potential anomalies.
  • • 11 weeks
  • • 13 weeks 6 days
  • • 11-14 weeks
  • • Measurement Criteria:
  • • Measurement Criteria:
  • • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Should be between 45-84 mm. Fetal Position: Fetus should be in the mid-sagittal plane and in a neutral position. Image Quality: The image must be magnified, and the widest space should be measured. Caliper Placement: The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space, ensuring the amnion is seen separately.
  • • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Should be between 45-84 mm.
  • • Crown-Rump Length (CRL):
  • • Fetal Position: Fetus should be in the mid-sagittal plane and in a neutral position.
  • • Fetal Position:
  • • Image Quality: The image must be magnified, and the widest space should be measured.
  • • Image Quality:
  • • Caliper Placement: The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space, ensuring the amnion is seen separately.
  • • Caliper Placement:
  • • Screening Efficiency:
  • • Screening Efficiency:
  • • NT Alone: Provides a 65% detection rate for Down syndrome. Combined Test: When combined with the Dual Marker test (beta hCG and PAPP-A), the detection rate for Down syndrome improves to 80%.
  • • NT Alone: Provides a 65% detection rate for Down syndrome.
  • • NT Alone:
  • • Combined Test: When combined with the Dual Marker test (beta hCG and PAPP-A), the detection rate for Down syndrome improves to 80%.
  • • Combined Test:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 6-8 weeks: This is too early for accurate NT measurement.
  • • Option A. 6-8 weeks:
  • • Option C. 14-16 weeks: This is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation, reducing the effectiveness of the screening.
  • • Option C. 14-16 weeks:
  • • Option D. 16-20 weeks: This period is too late for NT measurement, which should be performed in the first trimester.
  • • Option D. 16-20 weeks:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation is between 11-14 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 860, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 860, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: In a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA, what is the correct sequence of management? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

options.label: B
options.text: Intubation, cervical spine stabilization, IV cannulation, CECT

options.label: C
options.text: IV cannulation, cervical spine stabilization, intubation, CECT

options.label: D
options.text: IV cannulation, intubation, CECT, cervical spine stabilization

questions.correct_answer: A. Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cervical spine stabilization, intubation, IV cannulation, CECT is the correct sequence of management in a patient who presents to the casualty with an RTA.
  • ➤ The steps in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) include the following: primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation, secondary survey, and definitive care.
  • ➤ The ABCDE of trauma care include Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate), Breathing and ventilation assessment, Circulation assessment, Disability assessment, and Exposure, with environmental control. During airway securing, cervical spine should be stabilised first (with a hard cervical collar) prior to attempting any manoeuvres like endotracheal intubation.
  • ➤ Adjuncts to the primary survey include blood tests, ECG, pulse oximetry, urinary and gastric catheters, and radiographs.
  • ➤ Specialized imaging like CECT should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not constrained by time? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Goal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A goal is the ultimate desired state that a health program aims to achieve. It is not constrained by time, meaning that a goal does not have a specific timeline associated with it. Additionally, a goal is not necessarily attainable , as it represents the ultimate desired outcome.
  • • the ultimate desired state
  • • not have a specific timeline
  • • not necessarily attainable
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Objective: An objective is a specific, planned activity in a health program. Objectives are designed to help achieve the goal and are usually associated with a timeline .
  • • Option A. Objective:
  • • specific, planned activity
  • • timeline
  • • Option B. Target: A target is the degree of achievement of objectives and is always associated with a timeline.
  • • Option B. Target:
  • • degree of achievement
  • • timeline.
  • • Option D. Principle: The principles are generally guidelines or fundamental truths and do not specify timelines.
  • • Option D. Principle:
  • • guidelines or fundamental truths

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of health programs, a goal is the ultimate desired state and is not constrained by time or resources. It represents an " all or none" phenomenon and may not always be attainable.
  • ➤ all or none" phenomenon

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IVC compression

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.
  • • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness. Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.
  • • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome:
  • • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.
  • • Relief by changing position:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.
  • • Option A. Increased intracranial pressure:
  • • Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.
  • • Option C. Heavy meals:
  • • Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.
  • • Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient on cancer chemotherapy developed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Filgrastim

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Filgrastim is the drug used to increase immunity in patients with chemotherapy-induced neutropenia. It works by stimulating the production of neutrophils, thereby reducing the risk of infection. Other drugs like darbepoetin, oprelvekin, and iron dextran are used for different hematological conditions and do not directly increase neutrophil counts or improve immunity in neutropenic patients.

questions.text: In a screening examination conducted on a population of 1000 individuals for diabetes mellitus (DM), 90 individuals tested positive. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was performed, identifying 100 positive cases. What is the calculated sensitivity? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 90/100

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sensitivity is the proportion of true positive cases correctly identified by a screening test out of all actual positive cases identified by the gold standard test.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female presented in OPD as shown below. She is a known case of Diabetes Mellitus. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In diabetic patients presenting with black necrotic tissue and signs of invasive fungal infection in the nasal or orbital area, mucormycosis is the most likely diagnosis, requiring immediate and aggressive treatment to prevent potentially life-threatening complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old nurse in a busy city hospital is focused on infection control for general respiratory illnesses. Regular hand washing with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand rub is recommended to prevent the spread of infections. This recommendation falls under which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Primary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Levels of prevention
  • ➤ Levels of prevention
  • ➤ Primordial-Prevention of development of risk factors Primary- Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented. Secondary-Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications. Tertiary- Complications are present, death is being prevented.
  • ➤ Primordial-Prevention of development of risk factors
  • ➤ Primary- Risk factor is present, but disease is being prevented.
  • ➤ Secondary-Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications.
  • ➤ Tertiary- Complications are present, death is being prevented.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient having a ↓ MCV, ↓ MCH, ↓ transferrin saturation, ↓ serum ferritin, and ↑ Total iron binding capacity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Iron deficiency anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia is identified by microcytic hypochromic anemia with low serum ferritin, low transferrin saturation, and high TIBC, reflecting the body’s response to insufficient iron availability for hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mucicarmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.
  • ➤ Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: Apart from the abdomen, which body part is included in e-FAST? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thoracic cavity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ E-FAST stands for Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma, which is a bedside ultrasound examination used to evaluate trauma patients. It involves the use of a portable ultrasound machine to assess for free fluid in the abdomen, chest, and around the heart.
  • ➤ In addition to identifying free fluid, e-FAST can also be used to evaluate for other injuries, such as pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pericardial effusion. E-FAST has become a standard of care in trauma evaluation and is a valuable tool in the early detection and treatment of life-threatening injuries.

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hormone receptor staining

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include Hormone receptor staining.

questions.text: Water has accumulated in a container from a malfunctioning septic system, and mosquito larvae are observed. Based on the provided larval image, which mosquito species is it likely to be? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Culex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum, and loss of fetal movements. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Abruptio placentae, also known as placental abruption, commonly occurs in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. It is characterized by the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and often fetal distress or fetal death. The uterus may be tonically contracted in such cases.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Hypertensive Disorders: Abruptio placentae is frequently associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. Clinical Presentation: Painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements are hallmark signs. Uterine Contraction: The uterus may feel firm and tender, indicating a tonic contraction.
  • • Hypertensive Disorders: Abruptio placentae is frequently associated with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy.
  • • Hypertensive Disorders:
  • • Clinical Presentation: Painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements are hallmark signs.
  • • Clinical Presentation:
  • • Uterine Contraction: The uterus may feel firm and tender, indicating a tonic contraction.
  • • Uterine Contraction:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Placenta previa: Placenta previa involves painless vaginal bleeding due to the placenta covering the cervix. It generally does not cause decreased fetal movements unless there is severe bleeding leading to maternal and fetal compromise.
  • • Option B. Placenta previa:
  • • Option C. Hydramnios: Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) involves excessive amniotic fluid and does not typically present with bleeding.
  • • Option C. Hydramnios:
  • • Option D. Preterm labor: Preterm labor typically does not present with bleeding and is characterized by regular uterine contractions leading to cervical changes before 37 weeks of gestation. Prematurity in preterm labor is iatrogenic if induced.
  • • Option D. Preterm labor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Abruptio placenta should be suspected in a hypertensive pregnant woman presenting with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and loss of fetal movements, as it is commonly associated with hypertensive disorders and presents with these clinical features.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 1944
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg 1944

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. CXR shows a 3 cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with a significant smoking history and a peripheral lung mass larger than 2 cm, a CT guided biopsy is the next best step to diagnose the nature of the mass.

questions.text: The 1 st sign to be seen in Mg toxicity in a patient receiving MgSO 4 for eclampsia is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Loss of DTRs (Deep Tendon Reflexes)

Explanation:

  • • Detailed Explanation:
  • • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia : MgSO 4 is used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. While effective, it has a narrow therapeutic range, making monitoring for toxicity essential. Monitoring Signs : Loss of DTRs : This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact. Respiratory Depression : Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise. Cardiac Arrest : In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.
  • • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia : MgSO 4 is used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. While effective, it has a narrow therapeutic range, making monitoring for toxicity essential.
  • • Magnesium Sulfate in Eclampsia
  • • Monitoring Signs : Loss of DTRs : This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact. Respiratory Depression : Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise. Cardiac Arrest : In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.
  • • Monitoring Signs
  • • Loss of DTRs : This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact. Respiratory Depression : Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise. Cardiac Arrest : In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.
  • • Loss of DTRs : This is the earliest sign of magnesium toxicity. Clinicians regularly check for the presence of deep tendon reflexes to ensure they are intact.
  • • Loss of DTRs
  • • Respiratory Depression : Following the loss of DTRs, respiratory depression can occur if magnesium levels continue to rise.
  • • Respiratory Depression
  • • Cardiac Arrest : In severe cases, unchecked magnesium toxicity can lead to cardiac arrest.
  • • Cardiac Arrest
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cardiac arrhythmias : While significant, this is a later sign of magnesium toxicity and typically occurs after respiratory depression.
  • • Option A. Cardiac arrhythmias
  • • Option B. Hypotonia : This can be a symptom of magnesium toxicity but is not the first sign observed.
  • • Option B. Hypotonia
  • • Option D. Respiratory depression : This follows the loss of deep tendon reflexes and is a critical sign of advancing magnesium toxicity.
  • • Option D. Respiratory depression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs) is the first clinical sign of magnesium toxicity in patients receiving MgSO 4 for eclampsia. Continuous monitoring of DTRs is crucial to detect early toxicity and prevent severe complications.
  • ➤ Loss of Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs)

questions.text: Which among the following drugs decreases the serum parathyroid hormone levels? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Calcitriol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcitriol, the active form of vitamin D, decreases serum parathyroid hormone levels by increasing calcium absorption from the intestines and directly inhibiting PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands through its action on vitamin D receptors.

questions.text: HIV positive woman, not on any treatment, delivers a baby. Initial treatment for the newborn will include:(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nevirapine + Zidovudine X 6 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Low-risk infants:
  • • Low-risk infants:
  • • Infants born to mothers with suppressed viral load (<1000 copies/ml) done any time after 32 weeks of pregnancy up to delivery
  • • Infants born to mothers with suppressed viral load (<1000 copies/ml) done any time after 32 weeks of pregnancy up to delivery
  • • ARV Prophylaxis Options:
  • • Syrup Nevirapine (NVP) or Syrup Zidovudine# (in situations where NVP will not be effective): Infant born to a mother with confirmed HIV-2 or HIV-1 and HIV-2 combined infections Infant born to a mother who had received single dose of NVP during earlier pregnancy or delivery Infant born to a mother who is on PI-based ART regimen due to treatment failure
  • • Syrup Nevirapine (NVP) or
  • • Syrup Zidovudine# (in situations where NVP will not be effective): Infant born to a mother with confirmed HIV-2 or HIV-1 and HIV-2 combined infections Infant born to a mother who had received single dose of NVP during earlier pregnancy or delivery Infant born to a mother who is on PI-based ART regimen due to treatment failure
  • • Infant born to a mother with confirmed HIV-2 or HIV-1 and HIV-2 combined infections Infant born to a mother who had received single dose of NVP during earlier pregnancy or delivery Infant born to a mother who is on PI-based ART regimen due to treatment failure
  • • Infant born to a mother with confirmed HIV-2 or HIV-1 and HIV-2 combined infections
  • • Infant born to a mother who had received single dose of NVP during earlier pregnancy or delivery
  • • Infant born to a mother who is on PI-based ART regimen due to treatment failure
  • • Duration of ARV prophylaxis:
  • • From birth till 6 weeks of age
  • • From birth till 6 weeks of age
  • • High-risk infants
  • • High-risk infants
  • • Infants born to HIV-positive mother not on ART Maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery Maternal viral load not suppressed between 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery Mother newly identified HIV positive within 6 weeks of delivery
  • • Infants born to HIV-positive mother not on ART
  • • Maternal viral load not done after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery
  • • Maternal viral load not suppressed between 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery
  • • Mother newly identified HIV positive within 6 weeks of delivery
  • • Options for dual prophylaxis:
  • • Syrup NVP + Syrup Zidovudine
  • • Syrup NVP + Syrup Zidovudine
  • • Duration of Dual ARV Prophylaxis:
  • • In case of Exclusive Replacement Feeding (ERF): From birth till 6 weeks of age In case of Exclusive Breastfeeding (EBF): From birth till 12 weeks of age
  • • In case of Exclusive Replacement Feeding (ERF): From birth till 6 weeks of age
  • • In case of Exclusive Breastfeeding (EBF): From birth till 12 weeks of age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For newborns of untreated HIV-positive mothers, initial treatment includes Syrup NVP + Syrup Zidovudine 6 weeks (12 weeks in cases of exclusive breast feeding) to reduce the risk of mother-to-child HIV transmission.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented with hearing loss. On PTA, the amount of hearing loss was 56dB: (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular fixation without intact tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ossicular fixation with intact tympanic membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis often presents as progressive conductive hearing loss with an intact tympanic membrane, and the hearing loss can worsen during pregnancy. The classic finding is ossicular fixation, particularly of the stapes bone.

questions.text: At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.
  • • The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:
  • • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus. Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus
  • • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Subthalamic nuclei : The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.
  • • Option B
  • • Subthalamic nuclei
  • • Option C . Decussation of pyramidal tract : The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.
  • • Option C
  • • Decussation of pyramidal tract
  • • Option D . Olivary nucleus : The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.
  • • Option D
  • • Olivary nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

questions.text: Which among the following monitors is most commonly used to monitor the depth of anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bispectral index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bispectral index (BIS) is the most commonly used monitor to assess the depth of anesthesia, providing an EEG-derived measure of the cerebral effects of anesthetic drugs.

questions.text: A patient presents with diminution of vision. He has a H/o ATT intake. The causative drug is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethambutol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug most commonly associated with toxic optic neuropathy, causing diminution of vision in patients on ATT. Regular ophthalmic monitoring is crucial for patients on ethambutol to detect early signs of toxicity

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Beta-glucocerebrosidase is linked to Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by a deficiency in Glucose-6-phosphatase. Correct pairing of diagnostic markers and associated conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 64, 167,634
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 64, 167,634

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presented with arthritis. She had a history of fever and sore throat 1 week ago. On examination, you hear a pansystolic murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. What is the finding you will see in the biopsy? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Aschoff nodule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of sore throat followed by symptoms such as arthritis and carditis, acute rheumatic fever should be considered. The presence of Aschoff nodules in biopsy is pathognomonic for this condition, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: In a menstrual cycle, the primary oocyte undergoes meiotic division to produce 2 unequal daughter cells under the influence of the mid-cycle LH surge. What is the cause of LH surge? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Estradiol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sustained peak level of estrogen for 24–48 hours in the late follicular phase results in LH surge from the anterior pituitary
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynaecology page 68
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynaecology page 68

questions.text: Which of the options below does NOT result in water hardness? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Calcium carbonate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’ Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3) 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate) Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.
  • ➤ Hardness of water is defined as the ‘soap destroying power of water’
  • ➤ Hardness of water is expressed in terms of: milliequivalents per litre (mEq/litre) of CALCIUM CARBONATE (CaCO3)
  • ➤ 1 mEq/litre hardness = 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) per litre of water
  • ➤ Softening of water is recommended at level of hardness > 3 mEq/litre (>150 mg/litre of Calcium carbonate)
  • ➤ Temporary hardness of water is due to Ca++ and Mg++ Bicarbonates
  • ➤ Permanent hardness (Non-Carbonate hardness) is due to Calcium & Magnesium salts of Sulfates, Chlorides, Nitrates
  • ➤ Four main compounds causing Hardness: Calcium bicarbonates, Magnesium bicarbonates, Calcium sulfates, Magnesium sulfates.

questions.text: Identify the hemorrhage shown in the given image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subdural hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subdural hemorrhages, typically appear as crescent-shaped hyperdense areas on CT scans and in particular, require timely intervention to manage increased intracranial pressure and prevent permanent damage or death. They can present with symptoms ranging from mild headaches to severe neurological deficits, depending on the extent of the bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following pathology is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray is a classic radiographic finding indicative of a hollow viscus perforation. This is a critical sign that should prompt immediate medical evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with cancer is undergoing radiotherapy. She is given a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy daily for five days a week, for a total treatment duration of 6 to 8 weeks. What among the following explains this type of radiotherapy? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Conventional Fractionation radiotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conventional Fractionation radiotherapy involves delivering 1.8 to 2 Gy per day, five days a week, for 6 to 8 weeks, allowing for normal tissue recovery between treatments.

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visual field defects:
  • ➤ Visual field defects:

questions.text: What is the appropriate BIRADS category for a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) BIRADS 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the case of a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, the appropriate BIRADS category is BIRADS 2.
  • ➤ Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor that poses a low risk of malignancy. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) categories are used to assess the likelihood of malignancy of breast lesions seen on mammograms, ultrasounds, or MRI. Grades 1 and 2 have a very low probability of being malignant, while grade 3 has a slightly higher probability of malignancy.
  • ➤ Grades 4 and 5 are considered suspicious and warrant further investigation as they have a higher probability of malignancy.

questions.text: Which joint is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Synovial

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text: Identify the image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bier’s block, or intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), is used for anesthetizing a limb by injecting local anesthetic into a vein while using a tourniquet to confine the anesthetic to the limb.

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention. Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.
  • ➤ Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • ➤ Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.
  • ➤ Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9 th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10
